awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ecological Influences on Locomotor Performance in Free-Ranging Primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Many primate species are partially or completely arboreal, able to move adeptly over narrow, steep, and bending branches in trees. In this project, investigators will expand their research on the mechanics of walking and leaping in wild primates moving in their natural environments, to provide a deeper understanding of primate arboreality. The team will use advanced and durable video technologies that permit high-resolution measures of locomotion in the wild. The results of this project will further our understanding of locomotor adaptations that are thought to be central to the evolution of our early primate ancestors. The project will support undergraduate and graduate student training and will enhance K-12 STEM education and public outreach through high school programs and collaborations with established science outreach programs at UT Austin. Findings from this project will be relevant to primate conservation efforts, science education, and community outreach at the field locations. 

This project will test hypotheses about the proximate and ultimate determinants of primate locomotor adaptation through analysis of fifteen species of free-ranging strepsirrhines and cercopithecoids. The project expands upon the investigators' previous analysis of quadrupedalism among platyrrhines and includes a three-dimensional kinematic analysis of arboreal leaping. The investigators will document locomotor kinematics of primates moving in their natural habitats using multi-camera, high-speed, high-resolution videography, sampling arboreal locomotion on a range of substrates and quantifying standard kinematic spatiotemporal variables. The morphology of the arboreal locomotor substrates will be quantified using novel remote sensing methods, with specific measurements including substrate diameter, orientation, height above the ground, and compliance. By expanding the sampled range of locomotor behaviors, body sizes, substrates, and taxa, this project will facilitate a more comprehensive investigation of how substrate variation and phylogenetic history have influenced primate locomotor adaptation and evolution. Such knowledge is critical to understanding the adaptive context in which the distinctive aspects of primate locomotion evolved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The majority of primate species are partially or completely tree-dwelling (arboreal), and they often captivate observers with their ability to move with ease over narrow, steep, and bending branches. The goal of this project was to investigate the mechanics of walking and leaping in wild primates moving in their natural environments, to provide a deeper understanding of primate arboreal athleticism. Past studies of primate locomotor mechanics have largely come from laboratory-based research, but in this research we used advanced and durable video technologies that permit high-resolution measures of locomotion in the wild. Our results will further our understanding of locomotor adaptations that are thought to be central to the evolution of our early primate ancestors.

Project research was first designed to test hypotheses about primate locomotor adaptation through analysis of eight species of  free-ranging strepsirrhines in Ranomafana National Park and Anja Community Reserve, Madagascar (Eulemur rubriventer, Eulemur rufifrons, Hapalemur aureus, Hapalemur griseus, Lemur catta, Prolemur simus, Propithecus edwardsi, and Varecia variegata) and eight species of free-ranging cercopithecoids in Kibale National Park, Uganda (Allochrocebus lhoesti, Cercopithecus ascanius, Cercopithecus mitis, Chlorocebus aethiops, Colobus guereza, Lophocebus albigena, Papio anubis, and Piliocolobus tephrosceles). This research expands on our similar investigation of quadrupedal locomotion in eleven species of free-ranging platyrrhines at field sites in Costa Rica and Ecuador, resulting in a combined dataset on quadrupedalism for 27 primate species distributed across the extant radiation. This work represents an unprecedented dataset for the quantitative analysis of primate gait variability and its determinants in free-ranging primates moving in their natural environments. Though analyses are still ongoing, existing results support several general conclusions. Fundamentally, our field data generally corroborate laboratory studies of primate gait and locomotion, but capture additional aspects of locomotor variability and flexibility in response to the complexity of natural environments. For instance, we found evidence that lemurs adjusted some gait parameters based on their height in the canopy, suggesting that the risk of injury from falling may be an additional influence on primate gait that has – as of yet – received little attention (perhaps at least partly due to the difficulty of modeling this parameter in laboratory environments). Overall, our results suggest that primate gait patterns are not exclusively tailored to “precarious” supports (i.e., narrow or oblique substrates) but are used across a variety of supports. For example, in an analysis of limb joint postures in 14 species from our wild primate dataset (five platyrrhines, five cercopithecoids, and four lemurs) we found that joint postures changed very little in response to changing substrate parameters, though - as previously shown in laboratory studies - substrate orientation exerted a stronger influence than substrate diameter or compliance per se. Overall, our results routinely demonstrate significant differences in quadrupedal locomotor patterns among major taxonomic groups of primates - independent of any influence of substrate parameters on locomotion - suggesting that evolutionary history may be a better predictor of gait than substrate diameter or orientation.

Second, project research also included new quantitative analyses of arboreal leaping in wild primates, and - as in our analyses of quadrupedal locomotion - how the natural variability of the arboreal environment impacts leaping performance. Curiously, we found that in some cases the compliance (i.e., “bendiness”) of arboreal supports can actually enhance leaping performance in wild colobus monkeys., showing that the monkeys actively pump branches before leaping, augmenting their vertical velocity at leaping take-off, and harness the swaying motions of tree trunks to cross large gaps, augmenting horizontal velocity at take-off. This deliberate branch manipulation to produce a mechanical effect for stronger propulsion fits into the framework of instrumental problem-solving, and suggests a high level of cognitive involvement during primate arboreal locomotion. Additionally, to facilitate project research, we developed a standardized protocol for the three-dimensional analysis of primate leaping under wild conditions that could be adopted to quantitatively study the locomotor biomechanics of other animals moving in wild, free-ranging environments.  Overall, our results highlight the utility of the techniques newly developed for this research to promote understanding of both the proximate environmental and broader evolutionary determinants of primate locomotion.

This project has resulted in five peer-reviewed publications, and 13 professional conference presentations. At the University of Texas at Austin, it has provided training and mentorship for a graduate student and four undergraduate students. The UT PI and research team disseminated project research to K-12 students from underrepresented groups via UT Austin's Environmental Science Institute's "Hot Science Cool Talks" lecture series and to undergraduate students via involvement in the Undergraduate Research Workshop sponsored by UT Austin's Senate of College Councils. At NEOMED, project funds supported the training of a postdoctoral research fellow, a graduate student, four undergraduate students, and two high school students. The NEOMED PI taught three short courses on primate biodiversity and biomechanics at a local STEM high school affiliated with the university.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/16/2024
Modified by: Liza J Shapiro
